column17: Request that Utilize email for all authorisation requests, even if they require a phone call (so for phone call authorisations they also email) so there is a full audit trail of the request.

column7: Two individuals (CISO and Lead DevSecOps Engineer) have the capability to decrypt cardholder data as they have administrative access to the Cardholder Data Environment.
column8: Either of these individuals could take decrypted cardholder data and sell or use the data for some profit, exposing the company to massive regulatory concerns, reputational damage, and financial losses.
column9: Background checks, contracts, and additional agreements for individuals with access to cardholder data are in place.

column7: In the case of a data breach a notification needs to be made to the relevant supervisory authorities to avoid fines and legal ramifications.
column8: If a breach of personal data occurred we have obligations to notify the relevant supervisory authority (e.g. the ICO in the UK) to avoid facing fines.
column9: We have incident plans which include contact information for supervisory authorities, such as the ICO.

column7: In the case of a cardholder data breach a notification needs to be made to the relevant payment schemes to avoid fines and legal ramifications.
column8: If a breach of personal data occurred we have obligations to notify the relevant payment schemes (e.g. Visa, Mastercard, Amex) to avoid facing fines and to maintain our compliance such that acquirers and merchants will still allow us to process their card payments.
column9: We have incident plans which include contact information for payment schemes, such as Visa, Mastercard, and Amex.

column7: Maintaining up-to-date information on security threats, industry changes, and our security environment.
column8: If we do not maintain up-to-date and accurate information on industry threats and security environment changes then we run a risk of not maintaining a suitably secure environment, opening ourselves up to compromise and may miss out on regulatory changes, opening ourselves up to legal repercussions.
column9: We receive various newsletters and blog posts (e.g. ICO, PCI DSS), attend various webinars and seminars (such as Westminster eForum) and have direct involvement in the Electric Vehicle Charging industry through membership of the REA.

column7: Laptops and phones not being returned after termination of employment.
column8: Devices could contain sensitive company information which we need to control and we may lose the ability to control when the device leaves the organisation. There is also a direct monetary cost for devices leaving the organisation, when they could instead be re-issued.
column9:
Devices are requested to be returned upon termination of employment.
Devices are enrolled in Microsoft Intune and can be remotely wiped if this is necessary.

column7: Evidence of a security incident must be retained for further investigation.
column8: If evidence of a security incident or breach is not properly maintained an attacker could cover their tracks making it hard to find the culprit, it could be hard to identify the source of the attack or the vulnerability exploited, and it may be difficult to establish the full extent of compromise to guide recovery efforts effectively.
column9:
Hosted systems log to AWS CloudWatch, which is an immutable and centralised log storage with built-in redundancy. This makes it impossible to manipulate logs and hide evidence trails.
Windows logs (for administrative laptops and devices used by our staff for day-to-day operations) can log centrally to a Microsoft service, bit it isn't clear if this is correctly configured.
column17: Investigate Microsoft logging of endpoint activities for centralised reporting and immutable event logging for our staff issued devices, especially laptop computers.

column7: Information security events must be reported.
column8: Failure to report an information security event could have severe repercussions if the event turns out to have a substantial impact. If staff do not have a simple and well known route to report an information security event our chances of missing an event which results in a substantial impact increases.
column9: Regular security awareness training, onboarding security awareness training, and other regularly published guidance and training gives details on the email address to send any information security event report to.

column7: Equipment which is not properly maintained may expose vulnerabilities which malicious actors could exploit.
column8: If staff are not aware of their responsibilities to maintain the software patches on their laptops and mobile phones which connect to company resources then security vulnerabilities may not be patched in a timely manner increasing the potential for these vulnerabilities to be exploited.
column9: Most devices which connect to the Paythru network are managed and monitored remotely so patching can be semi-automated (certainly critical Microsoft patches are applied).

column7: Information security roles and responsibilities are unclear or not assigned, resulting in critical tasks being overlooked.
column8: Unauthorised access, delayed incident response, or regulatory non-compliance, leading to reputational and financial damage.
column9: Information security roles and responsibilities are clearly defined in our Information Security Policy, the Information Security Manual, and within individual policies and procedures.

column7: Security requirements are omitted or inadequately addressed during project planning or implementation.
column8: Introduction of vulnerabilities in new systems, resulting in potential data breaches or operational disruption.
column9: Our standard project workflow has a dedicated security impact review stage and all staff are trained on basic security awareness at least annually to support project management and specifications.

column7: ICT systems lack adequate redundancy, backup, or disaster recovery planning, failing during a disruptive event.
column8: Prolonged business interruption, data loss, or inability to meet contractual obligations.
column9: Paythru operates a robust Business Continuity Plan (which incorporates Disaster Recovery) and operates all critical infrastructure with built-in operational redundancy.

column7: Changes in regulations or internal policies are not communicated or enforced, resulting in non-adherence.
column8: Regulatory fines, legal action, or loss of certifications, damaging business operations and reputation.
column9: Policies are reviewed internally on an annual basis, or more frequently. Policy documentation is accessible to all staff on SharePoint or the Company Intranet. Staff must annually sign their understanding of specific policies, especially the Information Security Policy.
column17: We need to design a way for policy packs to be distributed on policy change, better version control for policies, and a mechanism for approval and confirmation of understanding. (See Risk #85, E I2-372)

column7: Residual sensitive data remains accessible on retired or repurposed devices due to improper deletion methods.
column8: Unauthorised disclosure of personal or confidential data, resulting in breaches and regulatory penalties.
column9: A documented information deletion policy is in place. Secure erasure tools are used for all media, and certificates of destruction are obtained for physical media disposal.

column7: Sensitive production data is used unmasked in non-production environments, exposing it to unauthorised personnel.
column8: Leakage of confidential or personal data, leading to privacy violations or reputational harm.
column9: Data masking and anonymisation techniques are applied to production data before use in development or test environments. Access to sensitive data is restricted and logged.

column7: Confidential information is unintentionally or maliciously sent outside the organisation via insecure channels.
column8: Data leakage causing reputational damage, customer loss, or legal consequences.
column9: Data leakage prevention (DLP) software is deployed on endpoints and email systems. Staff receive regular training on secure data handling and reporting suspected incidents.
column17: In addition to DLP we should take efforts to prevent use of external storage devices and provide better logging of access to sensitive materials. Risk #83 is a pre-requisite here and must first be resolved.

column7: Security events go undetected due to insufficient monitoring or logging.
column8: Prolonged attacker presence, increased damage, or untraceable incidents, undermining trust and compliance.
column9: Centralised logging and monitoring systems are in place. Security event logs are reviewed regularly and retained in accordance with policy. Alerts are configured for anomalous activity.
column17: Our logging for our production hosted infrastructure is robust, however our logging for our administrative and clerical environments needs improvement as many activities on endpoints are not centrally logged. Risk #83 is a pre-requisite of addressing this.

column7: Inconsistent or unsynchronised system clocks result in inaccurate event logs.
column8: Hindered forensic investigations, inability to prove compliance, or delayed incident response.
column9: All servers and network devices synchronise time using NTP to a trusted, central time source. Clock synchronisation monitored by automated systems and checked regularly.
column17: Our time management for our production hosted infrastructure is robust, however our time management for our administrative and clerical environments needs improvement as many endpoint clocks are not on enforced synchronisation. Risk #83 is a pre-requisite of addressing this.

column7: Privileged utility programmes are misused by unauthorised users to bypass security controls.
column8: System compromise, unauthorised changes, or data manipulation with severe operational or financial impact.
column17: When Risk #83 is resolved this will also be resolved as the treatment includes identifying and restricting access to privileged utility programmes.

column7: Lack of network segmentation allows attackers or malware to move freely across systems.
column8: Widespread compromise, data loss, or business disruption during a security incident.
column9: Network segmentation is enforced using VLANs and firewalls. Access between network zones is restricted and monitored. Regular network reviews are conducted.

column7: Users access malicious or inappropriate websites due to insufficient web filtering.
column8: Malware infections, phishing attacks, or data exfiltration, affecting system integrity and confidentiality.
column9: Web filtering is enabled on all endpoints and network gateways. Access to known malicious or inappropriate sites is blocked. Web filter logs are reviewed regularly.
column17: Web filtering needs to be deployed and enforced centrally, current efforts are applying only low intelligence and small scale protections, but the protections and restrictions need to be more robust.

column7: Systems are designed without considering layered security controls or secure engineering principles.
column8: Increased susceptibility to sophisticated attacks, leading to breaches or prolonged compromise.
column9: Secure system architecture and engineering principles are documented and applied to all new system designs. Design reviews include security considerations and are signed off by the CISO.

column7: Developers introduce vulnerabilities through insecure coding practices (e.g., lack of input validation).
column8: Exploitable weaknesses in applications, resulting in data breaches or service outages.
column9: Secure coding standards are documented and all developers are trained on them. Code reviews and automated vulnerability scanning are conducted for all development projects.

column7: Security testing is skipped or insufficient before deployment of new or updated systems.
column8: Undetected vulnerabilities exploited post-launch, causing data loss or operational disruption.
column9: Security testing, including vulnerability scanning and penetration testing, is mandatory prior to system go-live. Results are documented and remediation is tracked.

column7: Outsourced developers introduce insecure code or backdoors due to lack of oversight or contractual controls.
column8: Compromised software supply chain, leading to breaches, data loss, or regulatory issues.
column9: Secure coding standards exist and would be shared with any outsource development teams during technical initiation sessions and prior to production of code. We perform vulnerability scanning on all supplied application software.
column17: We have no formal outsource development policies at the moment, though we do not currently outsource any of our development we should prepare for the eventuality to inform any potential business future planning. Implement automatic security scanning (DAST, SonarQube), manual code review (PR), and other build checks prior to accepting code from outsource developers and deployment to live environments. (E I2-468)

column7: Development, test, and production environments are not separated, allowing unauthorised access to live data.
column8: Accidental or intentional data corruption, leakage, or disruption of production services.
column9: Development, test, and production environments are logically and physically separated. Access controls are enforced and monitored, and production data is not used in non-production environments.

column7: Non-conformance corrections and risk treatments could be ineffective (though assumed to be effective) because they are not reviewed.
column8: Non-conformances and risks could re-occur (potentially without notice) if assumed controls turn out to be ineffective.
column9: Annual internal audit covers all clauses and controls.
column17: Add a review process for Non-conformance corrections and risk treatments so that after a period of time from resolution they are reviewed to ensure they have remained effective. (E I2-478)

column7: Failure to enforce access restrictions and timely removal of permissions
column8: If access to critical systems is not effectively controlled, outsourced developers or internal users may retain or gain more privileges than necessary, potentially accessing or altering sensitive information or system configurations beyond their remit, even after their engagement ends. This could result in data compromise, service disruption, or regulatory non-compliance.
column9: NDA in place, IAM roles, MFA enforced, least-privilege policy, quarterly access review

column7: External developers mishandling source code or credentials
column8: Code or secrets leaked leading to compromise of production environment
column9: NDA in place, access restriction by repository, 2FA, audit logs

column7: Poorly controlled third-party access or weak contractor oversight
column8: Inadequate monitoring of third-party access could allow outsourced developers to bypass security processes or misuse repositories, leading to source code exposure or leakage of credentials and internal documentation.
column9: NDAs in place, code access scoped by project, 2FA enforced, supplier onboarding checklist

column7: Non-compliance with regulatory standards and data protection laws
column8: Failure to ensure that outsourced developers adhere to Paythrus PCI DSS and GDPR obligations could result in non-compliance penalties, data breaches, or reputational damage.
column9: Annual PCI DSS assessments, DPA/NDA with all contractors, mandatory training (evidence of training conducted/received)
